ingredients: 1 cup chopped leek (white and pale green parts only)
step_by_step_instructions: Mix 1 cup water and 0.19 teaspoons white wine vinegar in a large bowl.
Peel 0.25 pounds Jerusalem artichokes and place them in the vinegar water to prevent discoloration. Set aside.
Melt 0.38 tablespoons butter in a heavy large pot over medium heat.
Add 0.12 cups chopped onion, 0.12 cups chopped leek, and 0.25 garlic cloves, chopped. Sprinkle with salt and sauté until soft and translucent, stirring often, about 12 minutes.
Drain the artichokes, rinse well, and drain again. Cut into 1-inch pieces.
Add the artichokes to the onion mixture and sauté for 5 minutes.
Add 0.88 cups vegetable broth, increase heat to high, and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until artichokes are very tender, about 1 hour.
Cool slightly, then work in batches to puree soup in blender until very smooth.
Return to pot and rewarm soup, adding more broth by 0.03 cupfuls if needed to thin.
Stir in 0.06 cups heavy whipping cream and season to taste with salt and ground white pepper.
Divide soup among bowls and garnish with toasted pumpkin seeds. Optionally, top with a drizzle of pumpkin seed oil and some sautéed chanterelle mushrooms.

recipe_title: Mussels with Sausage, Coconut Milk and Lime
original_instructions:
Heat oil in heavy large saucepan over medium-high heat. Add onion, sausage, lemongrass, ginger and garlic and sauté 5 minutes. Add all remaining ingredients except cilantro and mussels and bring to boil. Reduce heat and simmer 5 minutes. Mix in half of cilantro. Meanwhile, place mussels in large pot. Cover and cook over medium heat until mussels open and release their juices, about 5 minutes (discard any mussels that do not open). Divide mussels among shallow soup bowls. Stir any mussel liquid into coconut-milk mixture; ladle over mussels. Sprinkle with remaining cilantro.
Heat oil in heavy large saucepan over medium-high heat. Add onion, sausage, lemongrass, ginger and garlic and sauté 5 minutes. Add all remaining ingredients except cilantro and mussels and bring to boil. Reduce heat and simmer 5 minutes. Mix in half of cilantro.
Meanwhile, place mussels in large pot. Cover and cook over medium heat until mussels open and release their juices, about 5 minutes (discard any mussels that do not open).
Divide mussels among shallow soup bowls. Stir any mussel liquid into coconut-milk mixture; ladle over mussels. Sprinkle with remaining cilantro.
ingredients: 8 ounces hot links sausage, cut into 1/2-inch pieces
2 cups fish stock or bottled clam juice
step_by_step_instructions: Heat 0.33 tablespoon of sesame oil in a heavy large saucepan over medium-high heat.

Add approximately 0.42 cup of thinly sliced red onions, 1.33 ounces of hot links sausage cut into 1/2-inch pieces, 0.07 cup of thinly sliced peeled lemongrass, 0.08 tablespoon of minced peeled fresh ginger, and 0.08 tablespoon of minced garlic.
Sauté the mixture for 5 minutes.

Add 0.33 cup of fish stock or bottled clam juice, 0.13 cup of canned unsweetened coconut milk, 0.5 tablespoon of fresh lime juice, 0.33 tablespoon of rice vinegar, 0.17 tablespoon of soy sauce, and 0.25 teaspoon of ground coriander to the saucepan.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes.
Mix in 0.04 cup of chopped fresh cilantro into the coconut-milk mixture.
Meanwhile, place 6 mussels in a large pot.
Cover and cook over medium heat until the mussels open and release their juices, about 5 minutes. Discard any mussels that do not open.
Divide the mussels among shallow soup bowls.
Stir any mussel liquid into the coconut-milk mixture and ladle it over the mussels.
Sprinkle with the remaining cilantro.

recipe_title: Fava Bean, Asparagus, and Arugula Salad with Shaved Pecorino
original_instructions:
Cut asparagus stalks on a long diagonal into 1/8-inch-thick slices, leaving 1-inch-long tips (reserve tips separately). Blanch asparagus tips (but not sliced stalks) in a 4-quart pot of boiling salted water 2 minutes, then immediately transfer with a slotted spoon to a bowl of ice and cold water to stop cooking. Return water to a boil and blanch fava beans 1 minute, then immediately transfer with slotted spoon to ice water to stop cooking. Drain asparagus tips and beans and gently peel skins from beans (it's not necessary to peel edamame, if using). Toss beans and asparagus (blanched tips and raw sliced stalks) in a bowl with 1 tablespoon oil and salt and pepper to taste, then divide among 4 plates. Toss arugula with remaining tablespoon oil and salt and pepper to taste and mound on top of vegetables. Shave thin slices of cheese over salad with a vegetable peeler (use about half of piece), then drizzle with vinegar.
Cut asparagus stalks on a long diagonal into 1/8-inch-thick slices, leaving 1-inch-long tips (reserve tips separately).
Blanch asparagus tips (but not sliced stalks) in a 4-quart pot of boiling salted water 2 minutes, then immediately transfer with a slotted spoon to a bowl of ice and cold water to stop cooking.
Return water to a boil and blanch fava beans 1 minute, then immediately transfer with slotted spoon to ice water to stop cooking. Drain asparagus tips and beans and gently peel skins from beans (it's not necessary to peel edamame, if using).
Toss beans and asparagus (blanched tips and raw sliced stalks) in a bowl with 1 tablespoon oil and salt and pepper to taste, then divide among 4 plates. Toss arugula with remaining tablespoon oil and salt and pepper to taste and mound on top of vegetables. Shave thin slices of cheese over salad with a vegetable peeler (use about half of piece), then drizzle with vinegar.
ingredients: 2 cups shelled fresh fava beans (2 1/2 lb in pods) or shelled edamame (fresh soybeans)
step_by_step_instructions: Cut 2 ounces of asparagus stalks on a long diagonal into 1/8-inch-thick slices, leaving 1-inch-long tips and reserve the tips separately.
Blanch the asparagus tips in a pot of boiling salted water for 2 minutes.
Immediately transfer the blanched tips with a slotted spoon to a bowl of ice and cold water to stop cooking.
Return the water to a boil and blanch 1/2 cup of shelled fava beans for 1 minute.
Immediately transfer the blanched beans to ice water to stop cooking.
Drain the asparagus tips and beans, then gently peel the skins from the beans.
Toss the peeled beans and asparagus (both blanched tips and raw sliced stalks) in a bowl with 3/4 tablespoon of olive oil and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Divide the mixture onto a plate.
Toss 1 ounce of arugula with the remaining 3/4 tablespoon of olive oil and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Mound the arugula on top of the vegetables.
Shave thin slices of Pecorino Romano over the salad using a vegetable peeler, using about 1 ounce of cheese.
Drizzle the salad with 1/2 teaspoon of balsamic vinegar.

original_instructions:
1. Boil a large pot of salted water. 2. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, combine all the ingredients except the flour. Blend well, then slowly stir in the flour until the mixture becomes a stiff batter. 3. Place a colander with large holes over the pot and, with a rubber spatula, press small amounts of the batter through the holes directly into the water. 4. As the spaetzle gradually rise to the surface of the boiling water, use a slotted spoon to transfer them to a serving dish. Serve immediately, while still warm.
1. Boil a large pot of salted water.
2. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, combine all the ingredients except the flour. Blend well, then slowly stir in the flour until the mixture becomes a stiff batter.
3. Place a colander with large holes over the pot and, with a rubber spatula, press small amounts of the batter through the holes directly into the water.

ingredients: 1 cup ricotta cheese, Greek yogurt, or buttermilk
step_by_step_instructions: Boil a pot of salted water.
In a bowl, combine 0.25 cup ricotta cheese, 0.75 egg, 0.25 teaspoon salt, 0.125 teaspoon white pepper, and 0.125 teaspoon grated nutmeg. Blend well.
Slowly stir in 0.625 cup all-purpose flour until the mixture becomes a stiff batter.
Place a colander with large holes over the pot and, with a rubber spatula, press small amounts of the batter through the holes directly into the boiling water.
As the spaetzle rise to the surface, use a slotted spoon to transfer them to a serving dish. Serve immediately, while still warm.

original_instructions:
For lamb: Whisk sugar, 3/4 cup salt, and 10 cups water in a large bowl until salt and sugar dissolve. Add lamb, cover, and chill for at least 12 hours and up to 2 days. Heat oil in a large heavy pot over medium-high heat. Add onions, garlic, rosemary sprig, thyme sprig, and bay leaf. Cook, stirring often, until onions are golden brown and soft, 10-15 minutes. Remove pot from heat and add wine, stirring and scraping up any browned bits from bottom of pan. Return pot to heat and simmer until wine is reduced by half, about 3 minutes. Remove lamb shoulder from brine; add to pot, along with broth. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer gently, partially covered and skimming fat occasionally, until lamb is fork-tender, 5-6 hours. Transfer lamb to a platter and remove bones. Cut or shred meat into bite-size pieces. If needed, boil cooking liquid in pot until reduced to 6 cups, 15-30 minutes. Season sauce with salt, if needed. Return lamb to pot. DO AHEAD: Lamb can be prepared 3 days ahead. Let cool slightly, then chill until cold. Cover and keep chilled. Discard fat and reheat before serving.

For garlic emulsion and garnish: Place eggs in a small saucepan and add water to cover by 1". Bring to a boil and remove from heat. Cover and let sit for 3 minutes. Transfer eggs to a bowl of ice water and let cool completely. Peel. Combine eggs, garlic, 3 tablespoons lemon juice, and 1/2 teaspoons salt in a blender. With the motor running, gradually add oil, blending until a creamy sauce forms. Season garlic emulsion with salt and more lemon juice, if desired. Cook broccoli in a large pot of boiling salted water until crisp-tender, about 4 minutes. Drain; rinse under cold water. Divide stew among bowls and garnish with broccoli, parsley, tarragon, and garlic emulsion.

Divide stew among bowls and garnish with broccoli, parsley, tarragon, and garlic emulsion.
ingredients: 1 bunch broccoli, stems reserved for another use, cut into small florets
Flat-leaf parsley and fresh tarragon leaves (for garnish)
step_by_step_instructions: Whisk 1.04 g sugar, 3.12 g salt, and 41.67 ml water in a large bowl until salt and sugar dissolve.
Add 90.72 g lamb shoulder, cover, and chill for at least 12 hours and up to 2 days.
Heat 2.08 ml oil in a large heavy pot over medium-high heat.
Add 0.33 medium onions, 0.33 garlic cloves, 0.08 rosemary sprig, 0.08 thyme sprig, and 0.08 bay leaf.
Cook, stirring often, until onions are golden brown and soft, about 10-15 minutes.
Remove pot from heat and add 41.67 ml wine, stirring and scraping up any browned bits from bottom of pan.
Return pot to heat and simmer until wine is reduced by half, about 3 minutes.
Remove lamb shoulder from brine; add to pot, along with 333.33 ml broth.
Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer gently, partially covered and skimming fat occasionally, until lamb is fork-tender, about 5-6 hours.
Transfer lamb to a platter and remove bones. Cut or shred meat into bite-size pieces.
If needed, boil cooking liquid in pot until reduced to 250 ml, about 15-30 minutes.
Season sauce with salt, if needed.
Return lamb to pot.
Place 0.17 large eggs in a small saucepan and add water to cover by 1 inch.
Bring to a boil and remove from heat. Cover and let sit for 3 minutes.
Transfer eggs to a bowl of ice water and let cool completely. Peel.
Combine eggs, 0.33 garlic cloves, 3.12 ml lemon juice, and 0.08 teaspoons salt in a blender.
With the motor running, gradually add 12.5 ml oil, blending until a creamy sauce forms.
Season garlic emulsion with salt and more lemon juice, if desired.
Cook 30 g broccoli in a large pot of boiling salted water until crisp-tender, about 4 minutes.
Drain; rinse under cold water.
Divide stew among bowls and garnish with broccoli, parsley, tarragon, and garlic emulsion.

original_instructions:
Boil potatoes in large pot of water just until centers can be pierced with sharp knife, about 20 minutes. Drain. Cover and refrigerate until well chilled. (Can be prepared 1 day ahead.) Peel potatoes. Using hand grater, coarsely grate potatoes into large bowl. Gently mix in green onions. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Beat eggs with cumin and gently mix into potato mixture. Form potatoes into 2 1/2-inch-diameter cakes (about 1 inch thick). Cover and refrigerate until ready to cook. (Can be prepared 6 hours ahead.) Heat 2 tablespoons oil in heavy large skillet over medium-high heat. Add potato cakes in batches and fry until golden brown, about 8 minutes per side, adding more oil as necessary.
Boil potatoes in large pot of water just until centers can be pierced with sharp knife, about 20 minutes. Drain. Cover and refrigerate until well chilled. (Can be prepared 1 day ahead.)
Peel potatoes. Using hand grater, coarsely grate potatoes into large bowl. Gently mix in green onions. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Beat eggs with cumin and gently mix into potato mixture. Form potatoes into 2 1/2-inch-diameter cakes (about 1 inch thick). Cover and refrigerate until ready to cook. (Can be prepared 6 hours ahead.)
Heat 2 tablespoons oil in heavy large skillet over medium-high heat. Add potato cakes in batches and fry until golden brown, about 8 minutes per side, adding more oil as necessary.
ingredients: 12 green onions (white and green parts), chopped
step_by_step_instructions: Boil 0.5 pounds of potatoes in a large pot of water until centers can be pierced with a sharp knife, about 20 minutes.
Drain the potatoes and cover them. Refrigerate until well chilled, which can be done 1 day ahead.
Peel the chilled potatoes.
Coarsely grate the potatoes into a large bowl using a hand grater.
Gently mix in 2 green onions, chopped.
Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Beat 0.33 eggs with 0.33 teaspoons of ground cumin.
Gently mix the egg mixture into the potato mixture.
Form the potato mixture into cakes that are 2.5 inches in diameter and about 1 inch thick.
Cover the potato cakes and refrigerate them until ready to cook, which can be done up to 6 hours ahead.
Heat 0.5 tablespoons of olive oil in a heavy large skillet over medium-high heat.
Add potato cakes in batches and fry until golden brown, about 8 minutes per side, adding more oil as necessary.

original_instructions:
Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 200°F. Stack 4 ovenproof plates on oven rack to warm. Heat 1 tablespoon oil in a 10-inch heavy skillet over moderate heat until hot but not smoking. Stack 2 tortillas in skillet and cook 30 seconds, then flip stack over with tongs and cook 30 seconds more. While second tortilla cooks on bottom, turn top tortilla over with tongs, keeping tortillas stacked. Flip stack again and cook in same manner, turning over top tortilla and flipping stack again so that both tortillas are softened and both sides puff slightly, then deflate (do not let them become browned or crisp). Wrap tortillas loosely in foil and keep warm in oven. Fry remaining tortillas in same manner, adding 1 tablespoon oil to skillet for each batch. (Do not clean skillet.) Purée tomatoes with their juice, onion, cilantro, chipotle, garlic, and salt in a blender until very smooth. Carefully add mixture to hot skillet (it may spatter) and simmer, stirring occasionally, until salsa is slightly thickened, about 10 minutes. Heat 1 tablespoon oil in a 12-inch heavy nonstick skillet over moderately high heat until hot but not smoking, then crack 4 eggs into skillet and cook 3 to 4 minutes for runny yolks, or to desired doneness. Transfer to a plate and keep warm, covered, then cook remaining 4 eggs in remaining tablespoon oil in same manner. Season eggs with salt and pepper. Spoon 1/4 cup salsa onto each plate and top with 2 tortillas, slightly overlapping them. Transfer 2 eggs to tortillas on each plate and top with some of remaining salsa. Sprinkle with cilantro.

Stack 2 tortillas in skillet and cook 30 seconds, then flip stack over with tongs and cook 30 seconds more. While second tortilla cooks on bottom, turn top tortilla over with tongs, keeping tortillas stacked. Spoon 1/4 cup salsa onto each plate and top with 2 tortillas, slightly overlapping them. Transfer 2 eggs to tortillas on each plate and top with some of remaining salsa. Sprinkle with cilantro.
ingredients: 2 (14- to 15-ounce) cans whole tomatoes in juice
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro plus additional for sprinkling
1 tablespoon chopped canned chipotle chiles in adobo
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat the oven to 200°F and place one ovenproof plate on the rack to warm.
Heat 0.75 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a 10-inch heavy skillet over moderate heat until hot but not smoking.
Stack 1 tortilla in the skillet and cook for 30 seconds, then flip it over with tongs and cook for another 30 seconds.
Flip the tortilla again, ensuring both sides are softened and puffed slightly, then deflate. Do not let it become browned or crisp.
Wrap the tortilla loosely in foil and keep it warm in the oven.

Purée 3.5 ounces of tomatoes with 1.06 ounces of their juice, 0.06 ounces of chopped white onion, 0.03 ounces of chopped fresh cilantro, 0.003 ounces of chopped canned chipotle chiles in adobo, 0.25 garlic cloves, and 0.13 teaspoons of salt in a blender until very smooth.
Carefully add the mixture to the hot skillet and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the salsa is slightly thickened, about 10 minutes.
Heat 0.25 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a 12-inch heavy nonstick skillet over moderately high heat until hot but not smoking.
Crack 1 egg into the skillet and cook for 3 to 4 minutes for runny yolks, or to desired doneness.
Season the egg with salt and pepper.
Spoon approximately 0.06 cups of salsa onto the warmed plate and top with the warmed tortilla.
Transfer the cooked egg onto the tortilla and top with some of the remaining salsa.
Sprinkle with a bit of cilantro.
